docs.lead_paragraph: The most terrifying threat of the holiday season is not Y2K computer failure. It's Al Gore's new idea that he and Bill Bradley should have nonstop debates for the next four or five months. ''We could have two debates every single week and get rid of all of the television and radio commercials,'' he proposed on ''Meet the Press'' last weekend. ''I'm willing to do it right now if you'll shake on it.'' He offered his hand to Mr. Bradley, who stared at it as if it were a seven-day-old mackerel.
docs.abstract: Gail Collins Op-Ed column finds most terrifying threat of this holiday season is not Y2K computer failure but Al Gore's new idea that he and Bill Bradley should start having nonstop debates for next four or five months; notes extreme boredom experienced by listeners, in contrast to heady Lincoln-Douglas debates of 1850's (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: THREE acquisitions and an agency's closing are making news. In the largest of the acquisitions, the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, which owns agencies like Draft Worldwide, the Lowe Group and the McCann-Erickson World Group, agreed yesterday to buy NFO Worldwide Inc. in Stamford, Conn., a leading market research company.

headline.main: Three weddings and a funeral: deals are made and a small specialty agency closes shop.

docs.abstract: Advertising column focuses on acquisition of NFO Worldwide by Interpublic Group of Companies, of Vivid Studios by Modem Media.Poppe Tyson, of Sive/Young & Rubicam by Powers & Associates and closing of Mulryan/Nash--small New York shop specializing in campaigns aimed at gay and lesbian customers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Vermont Supreme Court unanimously ruled today that the state must guarantee the very same protections and benefits to gay and lesbian couples that it does to heterosexual spouses. The court left it to the Legislature to either legalize gay marriage, which no state has yet done, or adopt a domestic partnership law, which would be the most sweeping in the country. To extend equal rights to homosexual couples ''who seek nothing more, nor less, than legal protection and security for their avowed commitment to an intimate and lasting relationship is simply, when all is said and done,'' the ruling said, ''a recognition of our common humanity.''

headline.main: Vermont High Court Backs Rights of Same-Sex Couples

docs.abstract: Vermont Supreme Court rules that state must give gay and lesbian couples same legal protections and benefits as heterosexual spouses enjoy, but leaves specifics to Legislature to decide; finds constitutional discrimination in denial of marriage licenses that confer inheritance rights, health insurance and other benefits; state Senate leader Peter Shumlin predicts it will be easier to get votes for domestic-partnership law than for gay marriage; Gov Howard Dean agrees, adding that same-sex marriage 'makes me uncomfortable, the same as anybody else'; plaintiff attorney Beth Robinson says domestic partnerships would not encompass benefits from federal government or private employers; photo of plaintiffs (M)
docs.snippet: The Vermont Supreme Court unanimously ruled today that the state must guarantee the very same protections and benefits to gay and lesbian couples that it does to heterosexual spouses. The court left it to the Legislature to either legalize gay...

docs.lead_paragraph: The St. Paul Companies agreed yesterday to acquire the MMI Companies for $10 a share, a total of $200 million. St. Paul, a Minnesota insurance provider, said the deal would create the largest integrated provider of insurance and risk management services for the health-care industry, generating $1 billion a year in premiums and fees. The deal valued MMI at a premium to its price on Friday, and the stock rose $4.8125 a share, to $8.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline.main: ST. PAUL TO BUY MMI COMPANIES FOR $200 MILLION

docs.abstract: St Paul Companies will acquire MMI Companies for total of $200 million (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore offered today to halt all radio and television commercials in his presidential campaign if Bill Bradley would do the same. But Mr. Bradley scoffed at what he called ''a ridiculous proposal'' and spurned it, almost laughingly, as a shallow political gimmick. In a challenge that set off the most pointed and personal exchanges thus far between the two Democratic competitors, Mr. Gore proposed that rather than saturate the airwaves with advertisements costing millions of dollars, the candidates debate twice a week during the primary season.

headline.main: NO RADIO OR TV? NO WAY, BRADLEY RESPONDS TO GORE

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore offers to halt all radio and television commercials in his presidential campaign if Bill Bradley will do the same, but Bradley scoffs at proposal, calling it a shallow political gimmick; exchange makes for scrappiest, most revealing moments of 60-minute encounter on Meet the Press, which includes sparring over health care, foreign policy, education, campaign finance and the Lewinksy scandal; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jackson Barrett Mahon, an American fighter pilot shot down over France in World War II who was one of several Allied airmen thought to have inspired the 1963 movie ''The Great Escape,'' died on Dec. 4 in a hospice in Las Vegas. He was 78. The cause was heart failure, his daughter Doris Keating Schlesinger said. Mr. Mahon lived in Henderson, Nev.

headline.main: Jackson Barrett Mahon, 78, Heroic World War II Flier

docs.abstract: Joyce Purnick Metro Matters column discusses findings in new surgeon general's report on America's mental health care; says that while report faults private insurance companies for failng to cover mental illness as much as physical ailments, it fails to inform public that Medicaid, Federal government's insurance program for poor, does not reimburse states for cost of treating most patients who need long term care in state psychiatric hospitals (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Former Senator Bill Bradley and Vice President Al Gore have been sniping at each other over health care for weeks, and their disagreements have become a way of defining the differences between the two candidates for the Democratic presidential nomination. In a televised debate today, the candidates continued to argue over the merits and details of their health care proposals, with each accusing the other of distorting his position.

headline.main: Health Care Proposals Help Define Democrats

docs.abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore and Bill Bradley continue their debate over health care; their plans are compared on the points of what they would cost, how many Americans they would cover, what they would do to Medicaid and how they would extend health care coverage to children (M)
docs.snippet: Former Senator Bill Bradley and Vice President Al Gore have been sniping at each other over health care for weeks, and their disagreements have become a way of defining the differences between the two candidates for the Democratic presidential...

docs.lead_paragraph: Americans who have complaints about the health care system may soon be in luck -- or maybe not. Many health care professionals expect the medical system in the United States to be overhauled so remarkably during the next two decades that many patients will not be able to recognize it. While such a notion may excite some consumers -- who hasn't fantasized about the death of health maintenance organizations? -- others will no doubt be riled by new procedures that actually provide less medical care and coverage than before.

headline.main: Health Care Consumers Can Expect Change, and a Shock or Two

docs.abstract: Many healh care professionals expect medical system in United States, for better or worse, to be significantly overhauled in next two decades; one of biggest changes is expected to be increasing role of patient in choosing his or her treatment, with consumers relying less on their doctors and more on Internet and prescription-drug advertising campaigns; consolidation is expected to dominate health insurance industry in next 20 years, meaning larger and more powerful helth care organizations and higher prices; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For several years, the big quest in biotechnology has been to determine the complete sequence of human DNA, the genetic code of life. Now, however, that task is nearing completion, and the biotechnology industry is facing an even tougher job -- deciphering that code so that new drugs and diagnostic tests can be developed. The coming post-sequencing era will bring huge changes to the industry. The causes and mechanisms of various diseases that now defy treatment will become known so that drugs can be developed much more precisely. Drug discovery will rely as much on software and databases of genetic information as it will on test tubes and white mice.

headline.main: In the Works: Drugs Tailored to Individual Patients

docs.abstract: With complete sequencing of human DNA approaching completion, there is growing belief in biotechnology industry that coming decades will bring shift from 'one drug treats all' approach to advent of treatments tailored to individual patients based on their genetic profiles; several treatments on the horizon noted; chart of biotechnology stocks; photo (M)
